CONFIDENTIAL
Tentative Minutes from Skornia Notes on Urbana Meeting, October 5, 1
In attendance were President GRAYDON AUSMUS, Treasurer FRANK SCH00IEY, former
President and present Director RICHARD Bc HULL, WILBUR SCHRAMM, and HARRY SKORNIA*
pie discussion revolved around an organized presentation on behalf of the NAEB
in which its objectives would be clearly stated as & part of a request for funds
for continuance of present services and the as,sumption of JCET and NCCET services
(if these organizations should be discontinued) which wou.ld be included in the
Washington office which the NAEB also proposes to set up* This proposal will
involve evaluation (including measuring the success of the JCET and the NCCET)
in getting EOT established in the United States, in comparison with the budget
expended for this purpose* It should also involve measurement of success to
date in getting EOT recognized as a legitimate, built-in, core curriculum part
of education, to be financed in a regular, rather than a special, way.
At the outset, as Wilbur Schramm pointed out, certain assumptions must be
made. In these assumptions we must define what we think will be the role of edu¬
cational television and radio. We must then go on to assume that if this role
is to be played in America certain services will be needed (without regard to
who performs each)o<>0*We then should base our proposal on a picture in which we
propose certain financing, and a recommended administrative setup,
Io Assumptions;
Among the assumptions vie must make is that the NAEB has a long-range future,
that- it has a broad fiscal base which rests on the services it can provide its
member stations partly defrayable through service chargesc It therefore has a
tax base which emphasizes the need for both television and radio to be built into
the budget of regular educational, stations. At this point Dick Hull quoted Harold
LasswelPs statement that in the twentieth century there is no still small voice
without the resonance of twentieth century mass communicationsa
Another assunption that must be made is that radio is here to stay for the
for see able future. In this assumption we must also visualize funds needed for
at least five years, indicating what we think will be the status of EOT, educa¬
tional radio, and the various projects at the end of these five yearso This will
be covered in greater detail under financial and administrative structure below*
lie Jobs To Do;
Among the jobs which must be done and functions performed are notably the
following:
1) Ways of meeting the fiscal, crisis, both for education as well as the com¬
munications media, need discovering* In this respect the analogy of
German community stations which are as independent as community EOT sta¬
tions in the U* S0 are to be* Hoever the German stations have a regular
base of fiscal support in the form of the taxes paid by each set owner
which gives them an adequate and regular budget*
2) Another job to be done involves the exchange of ideas, exchange of mate¬
rials, and doing whatever is necessary to be sure that better programs are
secured* We need a center to distribute programs, as well as sources of
programs for both television and radio* We need reports for EOT and radio
before Gongress, and throughout the nation, as we3.1 as abroad*
